div1.head: Military Orders for Jefferson Randolph Kean and James Pilcher, October 31, 1900
div1.p:
FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Spec orders Vol 2
1900
Kean - Pilcher

SPECIAL ORDERS, }
No. 256. }

HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY,
ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE,
Washington, October 31, 1900.

1. By direction of the Secretary of War, Private Frederick
Robbins, Siege Battery K, 5th Artillery, Fort Hamilton, New
York, having enlisted under false pretences, will be discharged
without honor from the Army by the commanding officer of
his station. Under paragraph 1386 of the Regulations this
soldier is not entitled to pay or allowances, and final state-
ments, except for deposits, shall not be furnished him.

2. By direction of the Secretary of War, Private Jacob
Joecken, Company H, 5th Infantry, Fort Sheridan, Illinois,
will be discharged from the Army, by way of favor, by the
commanding officer of his station. This soldier is not entitled
to travel-pay.

3. By direction of the Secretary of War, Private Andrew
Griffis, Hospital Corps, Presidio of San Francisco, California,
will be discharged from the Army, by way of favor, by the
commanding officer of that post. This soldier is not entitled
to travel-pay.

4. By direction of the Secretary of War, Private Albert
Stock, Troop B, 2d Cavalry, recruiting station, Cleveland,
Ohio, will be discharged without honor from the Army by the
officer in charge of that station, by reason of desertion. This
soldier is not entitled to travel-pay.

5. By direction of the Secretary of War, Recruits Morris
Farber, Edward M. Frye, Arthur Hammer, Michael Holler,
and Charles Schaefer, general service, Presidio of San Fran-
cisco, California, will be discharged from the Army by the
commanding officer of that post, by reason of being unsuited
to the service. These soldiers are entitled to travel-pay.

6. By direction of the Secretary of War, Private Joseph L.
Wright, Battery B, 2d Artillery, Fort Monroe, Virginia, will
be discharged without honor from the Army by the command-
ing officer of his station, by reason of his own misconduct.
This soldier is not entitled to travel-pay.

12. By direction of the Secretary of War, the following
changes in the stations and duties of officers of the Medical
Department are ordered:
✓

Major Jefferson R. Kean, surgeon, U. S. Volunteers, is re-
lieved from further duty in the Division of Cuba, and will
proceed to Fort McHenry, Maryland, and report in person to
the commanding officer of that post for duty and by letter to
the commanding general, Department of the East;

Captain George J. Newgarden, assistant surgeon, U. S.
Army, is relieved from duty at Fort McHenry, Maryland, to
take effect upon the arrival at that post of Major Kean, and
will proceed to Fort D. A. Russell, Wyoming, and report in
person to the commanding officer of that post for duty and by
letter to the commanding general, Department of the Colorado.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

13. By direction of the Secretary of War, leave of absence for
one month is granted 2d Lieutenant Frederick R. DeFuniak, jr.,
11th U. S. Infantry, to take effect upon the expiration of his
present sick leave of absence.

14. Leave of absence for one month is granted Captain
James R. Lindsay, 13th U. S. Infantry, to take effect upon the
expiration of his present sick leave of absence.

15. Major Cunliffe H. Murray, inspector general, U. S.
Volunteers, is hereby relieved from duty in the office of the
Inspector General of the Army, at these headquarters, and
will proceed to Chicago, Illinois, via Rochester, New York,
reporting to Major General Elwell S. Otis, U. S. Army, at the
latter point and accompanying him thence to Chicago, where
he will be placed on duty at the headquarters, Department of
the Lakes, under the orders of the department commander.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

16. Captain Thomas S. McCaleb, 23d U. S. Infantry, is trans-
ferred from Company H to Company F of that regiment.

17. By direction of the Secretary of War, leave of absence
for six months on surgeon's certificate of disability is granted
Captain Joseph L. Donovan, 22d U. S. Infantry.

18. The following-named officers, having been found by
Army retiring boards incapacitated for active service on ac-
count of disability incident thereto, their retirement from
active service October 31, 1900, by the President, under the
4
provisions of section 1251, Revised Statutes, is announced by
the Secretary of War:
✓
Captain James E. Pilcher, assistant surgeon, U. S. Army;
Captain Solomon E. Sparrow, 21st U. S. Infantry.

Captain Sparrow will proceed to his home. The travel en-
joined is necessary for the public service.
BY COMMAND OF LIEUTENANT GENERAL MILES:

H. C. CORBIN,
Adjutant General.
